# SKMutableTexture

**Class**

A texture whose contents can be dynamically updated.

## Declaration

```swift
class SKMutableTexture
```

## Overview

Normally, SpriteKit textures ([doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/SpriteKit/SKTexture] objects) are static, meaning that once created, their contents cannot be changed. This is important because a static image can be more efficiently managed inside the graphics hardware. However, sometimes you need to be able to update the contents of a texture dynamically. In this case, you should use a mutable texture. Because there is a performance penalty for updating the texture’s contents, consider other options first. For example, you can render a texture in hardware using the [doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/SpriteKit/SKView/texture(from:)] method and a node tree.

To use this class, create a mutable texture using either one of its creation methods or those of its superclass. Then, when you need to update the mutable texture object’s contents, call the [doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/SpriteKit/SKMutableTexture/modifyPixelData(_:)] method. Your block is called with the location of the texture in memory. Your block should update this texture and then return.

## Creating an Empty Mutable Texture

- **init(size:pixelFormat:)**: Initializes an empty texture with a specific size and format.
- **init(size:)**: Initializes an empty texture with a specific size.

## Modifying a Mutable Texture’s Contents

- **modifyPixelData(_:)**: Modifies the contents of a mutable texture.

## Textures

- **Maximizing Texture Performance**: Speed up image display and enable more images to be displayed at one time.
- **SKTexture**: An image, decoded on the GPU, that can be used to render various SpriteKit objects.
- **SKTextureAtlas**: A collection of textures optimized for storage and drawing performance.
